paragraphs.text:
%md
# Spark Data Partitioning

Welcome to the notebook with the exercises for the fifth session. You’re halfway on the path to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!
If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.
 
In this notebook you will be doing four exercises aimed at:
 - Looking at the data distribution of the partitions stored in your cluster.
 - Use different partitioning approaches to understand which is the best approach.
 - Understand the impact of the partitioning on the I/O functions.

msg.data:
Spark Data Partitioning

Welcome to the notebook with the exercises for the fifth session. You’re halfway on the path to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!
If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

In this notebook you will be doing four exercises aimed at:
- Looking at the data distribution of the partitions stored in your cluster.
- Use different partitioning approaches to understand which is the best approach.
- Understand the impact of the partitioning on the I/O functions.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise 1- Partitions and data distribution

In this exercise, you will look at the the data contained in different partitions. Pay attention to how the data is distributed between the partitions depending on how they are created.

You are expected to use the DataSet sample `transactions`, which contains monetary transactions for users in the world.

msg.data:
Exercise 1- Partitions and data distribution

In this exercise, you will look at the the data contained in different partitions. Pay attention to how the data is distributed between the partitions depending on how they are created.

You are expected to use the DataSet sample transactions, which contains monetary transactions for users in the world.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

TransactionSchema = ['name', 'amount', 'country']

transactions = [
    ('Bob', 100, 'United Kingdom'),
    ('James', 15, 'United Kingdom'),
    ('Marek', 51, 'Poland'),
    ('Johannes', 200, 'Germany'),
    ('Paul', 75, 'Poland'),
    ('Bob', 35, 'Mexico'),
    ('James', 21, 'Germany')
]

case class Transactions(name:String, amount:Long, country:String)

val transactions = List(
    Transactions("Bob", 25, "MX"),
    Transactions("James", 15, "United Kingdom"),
    Transactions("Marek", 51, "Poland"),
    Transactions("Johannes", 200,"Germany"),
    Transactions("Paul", 75, "Poland"),
    Transactions("Bob", 35, "Mexico"),
    Transactions("James", 21, "Germany")
)

%md

The following code snippet creates a data frame and outputs you the number of partitions, partitioner and partition structure.

msg.data: The following code snippet creates a data frame and outputs you the number of partitions, partitioner and partition structure.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession, Row
    
df = spark.createDataFrame(transactions, TransactionSchema)

print("Number of partitions: {}".format(df.rdd.getNumPartitions()))
print("Partitioner: {}".format(df.rdd.partitioner))
print("Partitions structure: {}".format(df.rdd.glom().collect()))

import org.apache.spark.sql.Row


val df = spark.createDataFrame(transactions)

df.rdd.getNumPartitions
df.rdd.partitioner
df.rdd.glom().collect()

%md
Look at the output and answer the following questions:
    - Names on partition 1
    - Amounts on partition 2
    - Why is the partitioned `None`?

msg.data:
Look at the output and answer the following questions:
- Names on partition 1
- Amounts on partition 2
- Why is the partitioned None?

paragraphs.text:
%md
**REPARTITIONING:** The following code repartitions the original DataFrame and outputs the same information.

msg.data: REPARTITIONING: The following code repartitions the original DataFrame and outputs the same information.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df2 = df.repartition("country")
    
print("\nAfter 'repartition()'")
print("Number of partitions: {}".format(df2.rdd.getNumPartitions()))
print("Partitioner: {}".format(df2.rdd.partitioner))
print("Partitions structure: {}".format(df2.rdd.glom().collect()))

val df2 = df.repartition($"country")

df2.rdd.getNumPartitions
df2.rdd.partitioner
df2.rdd.glom().collect()

%md
Look at the output and answer the following questions:
 - Amounts on partition 1
 - Names on partition 2
 - What is the main difference?

msg.data:
Look at the output and answer the following questions:
- Amounts on partition 1
- Names on partition 2
- What is the main difference?

paragraphs.text:
%md
Remember more partitions != uniform partition distribution. So more partitions is not necessarily the answer, in fact if you end up having too many partitions you may bump into a problem with very small files.

msg.data: Remember more partitions != uniform partition distribution. So more partitions is not necessarily the answer, in fact if you end up having too many partitions you may bump into a problem with very small files.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise 2 - Partitioning approaches

Using the same dataset, create new datasets, try partitioning using each one of the columns. This means you will end with 4 distinct datasets.

msg.data:
Exercise 2 - Partitioning approaches

Using the same dataset, create new datasets, try partitioning using each one of the columns. This means you will end with 4 distinct datasets.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df2 = df.repartition("name")
    
print("\nAfter 'repartition()' with column 'name'")
print("Number of partitions: {}".format(df2.rdd.getNumPartitions()))
print("Partitioner: {}".format(df2.rdd.partitioner))
print("Partitions structure: {}".format(df2.rdd.glom().collect()))

val df2 = df.repartition($"name")

df2.rdd.getNumPartitions
df2.rdd.partitioner
df2.rdd.glom().collect()

%md
After printing the number of partitions, partitioner and partitions structure, answer the following question: 
 - In this case, what is the best approach?
 - How can you determine that?

msg.data:
After printing the number of partitions, partitioner and partitions structure, answer the following question:
- In this case, what is the best approach?
- How can you determine that?

paragraphs.text:
%md
As you can see, the repartitioning has a direct effect on the distribution of the information, using the correct column is essential. For knowing the most appropriate column, you need to be familiar with the data, there is no workaround.

msg.data: As you can see, the repartitioning has a direct effect on the distribution of the information, using the correct column is essential. For knowing the most appropriate column, you need to be familiar with the data, there is no workaround.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise 3 - I/O with single and multiple files

Now, look at reading and writing. You already know this is a costly operation. Regardless, there are strategies for troubleshooting or improving the reading and writing performance. This exercise requires you to Read and Write a DataSet in a single file and multiple files to compare performance.

Question: How do you determine the best approach?
Note: unless you control what is being written, you can only make recommendations on the file sizes for you to read later. If you are given one big block then your fate is sealed.

msg.data:
Exercise 3 - I/O with single and multiple files

Now, look at reading and writing. You already know this is a costly operation. Regardless, there are strategies for troubleshooting or improving the reading and writing performance. This exercise requires you to Read and Write a DataSet in a single file and multiple files to compare performance.

Question: How do you determine the best approach?
Note: unless you control what is being written, you can only make recommendations on the file sizes for you to read later. If you are given one big block then your fate is sealed.

paragraphs.text: %md First let's read the data. The dataset is quite big, so let's take a small sample instead:

msg.data: First let’s read the data. The dataset is quite big, so let’s take a small sample instead:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df = spark.read.json("gs://de-training-input/alimazon/50000/client-orders/*.gz") \
    .sample(False, 0.2)  # take 20% of the data without replacement
df.count()

val df = spark.read.json("gs://de-training-input/alimazon/50000/client-orders/*.gz")
    .sample(false, 0.2) // take 20% of the data without replacement
df.count()
%md **`NOTE:`** Do not forget to set you username here

msg.data: NOTE: Do not forget to set you username here

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
username = "<user-name>"
val username = "<user-name>"

%md Let's write our data using different partitions.
Confirm in GCP that the dataset was written in the number of specified partitions.

msg.data:
Let’s write our data using different partitions.
Confirm in GCP that the dataset was written in the number of specified partitions.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df.repartition(1).write.json("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-1part/".format(username))
df.repartition(6).write.json("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-6part/".format(username))

df.repartition(1).write.json(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-1part/")
df.repartition(6).write.json(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-6part/")
%md Let's experiment a bit more reading and writing using different numbers of partitions:

msg.data: Let’s experiment a bit more reading and writing using different numbers of partitions:

paragraphs.text: %md Here is the example for reading from one file and writing to one file

msg.data: Here is the example for reading from one file and writing to one file

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df1 = sqlContext.read.json("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-1part/".format(username))
df1.repartition(1).write.csv("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-1in-1out/".format(username))

val df1 = spark.read.json(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-1part/")
df1.repartition(1).write.csv(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-1in-1out/")
%md Here is the example for reading from multiple files and writing to multiple files

msg.data: Here is the example for reading from multiple files and writing to multiple files

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df6 = sqlContext.read.json("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-6part/".format(username))
df6.repartition(6).write.csv("gs://de-training-output-{}/client-orders-6in-6out/".format(username))

val df6 = spark.read.json(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-6part/")
df6.repartition(6).write.csv(s"gs://de-training-output-$username/client-orders-6in-6out/")
%md Explore using different number of partitions, reading from 1 file and writing to 4

msg.data: Explore using different number of partitions, reading from 1 file and writing to 4

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Exercise 4 - Flights dataset partitions size

The next code help you to display the size of each partition, we are going to generate a sample dataset

msg.data:
Exercise 4 - Flights dataset partitions size

The next code help you to display the size of each partition, we are going to generate a sample dataset

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from itertools import chain
from pyspark.sql import Row

sample_dataset = spark.createDataFrame(chain([(i, 0) for i in range(1, 100001)], [(i, j) for i in range(1, 101) for j in range(1, 101)])).cache()
print(sample_dataset.rdd.getNumPartitions())
partitions = sample_dataset.rdd.mapPartitions(lambda part: [Row(value=len(list(part)))])
spark.createDataFrame(partitions).show()

val sampleDataSet = ((1 to 100000).map((_,0))++(1 to 100).flatMap(i => (1 to 100).map((_,i)))).toDS.cache
println(sampleDataSet.rdd.getNumPartitions)
val partitions = sampleDataSet.mapPartitions(iter => Seq(iter.size).iterator)
partitions.show()

%md
Now, using your acquired knowledge of former sessions, load the flights DataSet and display the size of the partitions

msg.data: Now, using your acquired knowledge of former sessions, load the flights DataSet and display the size of the partitions
